text:
Please see the README and commits for additions since its building up to quite a few now =)

With the addition of the OAuth class (not sure its a good name) it is now very simple to use the OAuthLib features for any client interacting with an OAuth server. Convenience methods for anyone implementing an OAuth server are on their way and will include verification of authorization headers, request uri queries and form encoded bodies with all three signatures methods. A method for generating any type of token is already added and I will need to research a bit more what other methods might be convenient.
title: Client use almost done (server use in planning)
Client use almost done (server use in planning)

text: I hope this can get merged soon!
Hey Ibâ€”I haven't forgotten about this awesome pull req, I've just been drowning in lots of other stuff. I hope I'll be able to finish reviewing the code tonight.
Since we've moved beyond this point now, I'm going to close this pull request.
Fixed a few bugs in oauth.py, added 100% test coverage
Removed accidentially included coverage file
Added sign plain and rsa support
Updated rsa
Added generated private key + comments
Moved tests to basedir
Fixed import in verify_spec
Confirmed RSA-SHA1 working
Changed realm to optional as per 3.5.1.
Added order_parameters which orders them according to 3.5.(1/2/3)
Added support for Form-Encoded Body 3.5.2 and Request URI Query 3.5.3
Fixed a few bugs, added a twitter test
Auth header now only includes oauth headers. Fixed a misunderstanding of ordering.
Small refactoring
A first try at documenting
More doc changes
Added convenience class OAuth
Updated README to use new OAuth class
Added verification methods for server use
More tests and some rsa bugfixes
Fixed plaintext bug + more tests
Added tests for invalid input
New flask example application
Small cleanup

Added the OAuth class to simplify working with the methods in OAuthLib. Using OAuth is now very straightforward and can be as simple as

o = OAuth(client_key="some key", client_secret="secret")
header = o.auth_header("http://www.example.com/authorize")

where header will be a string formatted for use as an Authorization header in a request.
title: (None, None, None)

text:
Fixed domain to lower case as per 3.4.1.2.
Added support for extracting query parameters as per 3.4.1.3.1.
The parameters does not have to be unique, thus I have modified for use of a list of tuples instead of a dictionary
The parameters were escaped one time to much, removed.
Both client and access secret can be empty, not only access. Per 3.4.2.
Added a few tests based on the RFC and http://hueniverse.com/oauth/guide/authentication/
title: (None, None, None)
